H0.text: In which year did women get the vote at 21 in the UK. 1918

H1.text: In which year did women get the vote at 21 in the UK. 1920

H2.text: In which year did women get the vote at 21 in the UK. 1922

H3.text: In which year did women get the vote at 21 in the UK. 1929

A4.text: The bill became law on 2 July 1928.

A5.text: Prior to this act only women over 30 who met minimum property qualifications could vote.

A6.text: The Representation of the People (Equal Franchise) Act was enacted in 1928.

A7.text: In 1928 the Conservative government passed the Representation of the People (Equal Franchise) Act 1928 equalising the franchise to all persons, male and female, over the age of 21.

A8.text: In 1928 the Representation of the People (Equal Franchise) Act gave women the vote on the same terms as men.

A9.text: Women gained the right to vote in 1918 to 1928.

A10.text: The 1928 act gave the vote to all women aged over 21, regardless of any property qualification, which added another five million women to the electorate.

A11.text: Women over 30 years old received the vote if they were registered property occupiers (or married to a registered property occupier) of land or premises with a rateable value greater than Â£5 or of a dwelling-house and not subject to any legal incapacity, or were graduates voting in a university constituency.

A12.text: The first UK general election with equal franchise for women occurred in 1929.
